By Ron Cassie
Opening photo: Thames Street, foot of Broadway, May 1940. Ã¢Â€Â”Courtesy of Tony Norris
The Gritty History (and Gentrification) of Fells Point
By Ron Cassie
Opening photo: Thames Street, foot of Broadway, May 1940. Ã¢Â€Â”Courtesy of Tony Norris
June 2023
When the Chasseur returned and saluted Fort McHenry after the warÃ¢Â€Â™s end, its
crew were hailed as heroes. The already legendary schooner was dubbed the Ã¢Â€ÂœPride
of Baltimore.Ã¢Â€Â Its shipÃ¢Â€Â™s captain, the renowned Thomas Boyle, who had lost men
in battle and had been wounded himself, praised Roberts for displaying Ã¢Â€Âœthe most
intrepid courage.Ã¢Â€Â Readjusting to civilian life as a free Black carpenter and laborer,
the ex-privateer purchased a home for $150 on Ann Street in Fells Point. Such was
RobertsÃ¢Â€Â™ reputation, that over the ensuing decades, despite the horrific racism of the era, he marched in uniform alongside the cityÃ¢Â€Â™s prominent citizens
on civic occasions. His 1861 obituariesÃ¢Â€Â”he lived to 95Ã¢Â€Â”recalled
his patriotism, Ã¢Â€Âœmany hair-breath escapes,Ã¢Â€Â and desire to always
be remembered as Ã¢Â€Âœone of the defenders of his native city should
the necessity have arrived to take up arms in its defense.Ã¢Â€Â
His Ã¢Â€Âœbrave character,Ã¢Â€Â it was noted, was Ã¢Â€Âœadorned with amicable
disposition,Ã¢Â€Â such that Ã¢Â€Âœnews of death will cause
heartfelt sorrow.Ã¢Â€Â
Battle
between the
Chasseur, a Fells
Point privateer, and
British schooner
St. Lawrence off
Havanna, 1815. Ã¢Â€Â”Adam Weingartner, public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Free Black seaman
and a hero of the
War of 1812,
George Roberts Ã¢Â€Â”Courtesy of the Maryland Center for History and Culture, PVF
Fells Point reflections. Ã¢Â€Â”Video by J.M. Giordano
Early Fells
Point developer,
Ann Bond Fell. Ã¢Â€Â”Courtesy of the Maryland Center for History and Culture, 1986.105.4
Pay day for the stevedores, c. 1905. Ã¢Â€Â”Library of Congress
emarkably, the streets of Fells Point, like
many in the earliest years of the city,
were not formally segregated during its
so-called Ã¢Â€Âœgolden era,Ã¢Â€Â which peaked
with the War of 1812 and lasted until the Civil War.
(BaltimoreÃ¢Â€Â™s infamous housing segregation law,
which stated that no Black resident could move onto
a block in which the majority of the residents were
white and vice versa, came in 1910.) All seven of the
residential alleys in Fells Point had white and Black
households, as Mary Ellen Hayward, author of BaltimoreÃ¢Â€Â™s
Alley Houses, discovered when she examined
the cityÃ¢Â€Â™s first directory to note Ã¢Â€Âœhouseholders of colorÃ¢Â€Â
in 1808. Eight of the larger streets, too, were at least somewhat integrated with Black caulkers, laborers,
laundresses, blacksmiths, barbers, and their
childrenÃ¢Â€Â”a trend Hayward traces through subsequent
directories. When Douglass, known as Frederick
Bailey as a boy, lived in Fells Point with the
slave-owning Auld family, Ã¢Â€Âœa German baker
had a shop on the southwest corner of Aliceanna
and Happy Alley,Ã¢Â€Â Hayward writes, Ã¢Â€Âœbut there was
also a Ã¢Â€Â˜colored groceryÃ¢Â€Â™ on the same block.Ã¢Â€Â
Black maritime business owner Isaac Myers, c. 1875. Ã¢Â€Â”LIBRARY OF CONGRESS
Ã¢Â€ÂœThat said, Frederick DouglassÃ¢Â€Â™
life changed dramatically because
he was sent to Baltimore,Ã¢Â€Â continues
Fields. Ã¢Â€ÂœHe might not have survived
otherwise. But once heÃ¢Â€Â™s here,
he also sees Black men, women, and
children auctioned off at the foot of Broadway and others separated
from their families and put on ships headed to New Orleans.Ã¢Â€Â
Ã¢Â€ÂœThe light broke in upon me by degrees. I went one day down on
the wharf of Mr. Waters; and seeing two Irishmen unloading a scow
of stone, I went, unasked, and helped them,Ã¢Â€Â recalls Douglass in
his 1845 memoir. Ã¢Â€ÂœWhen we had finished, one of them came to me
and asked me if I were a slave. I told him I was. He asked, Ã¢Â€Â˜Are ye a
slave for life?Ã¢Â€Â™ I told him that I was. The good Irishman seemed to be
deeply affected by the statement. He said to the other that it was a
pity so fine a little fellow as myself should be a slave for life. He said
it was a shame to hold me. They both advised me to run away to the
north; that I should find friends there, and that I should be free.Ã¢Â€Â
Ã¢Â€ÂœFells Point is a place with a lot of history, a lot of issues, a lot
of different people from all walks of life thrown together in a tight
geographic area,Ã¢Â€Â Fields says. Ã¢Â€ÂœItÃ¢Â€Â™s the most fascinating neighborhood
in the city.Ã¢Â€Â
Local historian
Lou Fields stands next
to the Frederick Douglass
memorial sculpture.-Photography By J.M. Giordano
Tugboats at Fells Point, circa 1950s.Ã¢Â€Â”Photography by Tom Scilipoti
It was in the middle of the Fells Point Ã¢Â€ÂœStop the
RoadÃ¢Â€Â citizen uprising in 1972 that Tony and Laura
Norris stumbled across a dingy bar called The Lone
Star among the vacant rowhomes and dilapidated
boardinghouses. Both were musicians and teachers,
but Laura had gotten ill and couldnÃ¢Â€Â™t work for a period
and while they were figuring out what to do next, a
friend ventured to Fells Point looking for office space.
Unable to find anything suitable, a realtor pointed
him toward a small saloon for sale. Ã¢Â€ÂœHe came back
and said, Ã¢Â€Â˜LetÃ¢Â€Â™s buy a bar,Ã¢Â€Â™Ã¢Â€Â the now-82-year-old Tony
Norris recalls. Ã¢Â€ÂœSo, I called a Baltimore friend who was
in California teaching, and said, Ã¢Â€Â˜Loan me $3,000,Ã¢Â€Â™ or
whatever it was for the down payment. At that time,
you could buy almost everything in the neighborhood.
I think we paid $14,000 for the liquor license
and the building, but there wasnÃ¢Â€Â™t much there. There
was an old room in the back that had a kitchen that
had never been finished. One of our customers who
was handy said, Ã¢Â€Â˜Well, IÃ¢Â€Â™ll help fix the kitchen up.Ã¢Â€Â™Ã¢Â€Â
From top: BerthaÃ¢Â€Â™s
owners Laura and Tony Norris
in front of their beloved
bar and restaurant today; the memorial stained glass
window and the inspiration
for the name of BerthaÃ¢Â€Â™s.Ã¢Â€Â”PHOTOGRAPHY BY J.M. GIORDANO
Leadbetters
Tavern, the CatÃ¢Â€Â™s Eye
Pub, and The Horse You Came In On in the 1970s.Ã¢Â€Â”COURTESY OF THE SOCIETY FOR THE PRESERVATION OF FEDERAL HILL AND FELLÃ¢Â€Â™S POINT
In 1975, Irish-American Kenny Orye, who convinced some he
ran guns for the IRA, and Tony and Ana Marie Cushing opened the
CatÃ¢Â€Â™s Eye Pub on Thames Street, taking their name from a West Virginia
distillery where OryeÃ¢Â€Â™s uncle bought his moonshine. Contrary to whatÃ¢Â€Â™s been published elsewhere,
Ana Marie Cushing says with a smile,
the previous Harbor View tavern
there had not been a biker hangout,
but a lesbian bar. By the late 1970s
and early Ã¢Â€Â™80s, the CatÃ¢Â€Â™s EyeÃ¢Â€Â™s back
room had become a place to be after
closing time, recalled Steve Bunker,
a former seaman who operated the
nearby China Sea Trading Company with a parrot perched on his
shoulder. Ã¢Â€ÂœAt 3 a.m. you could run into politicos, hookers, sailors,
deal-makers, illegal Irishmen, riffraff, and refugees,Ã¢Â€Â Bunker, who
now lives in Maine, wrote years later in the Fells Point newsletter.
Ã¢Â€ÂœYou didnÃ¢Â€Â™t ask too many questions about your stool mates, you just
drank your beer, passed a joint, and enjoyed the company.Ã¢Â€Â
The music and bar crawl culture developed over time as more
pubs opened kitchens and got permits for live music. But things
were not excactly popping in the early Ã¢Â€Â™7os. Ã¢Â€ÂœWhen first opened, someone would say, Ã¢Â€Â˜LetÃ¢Â€Â™s go over to The Horse
or the CatÃ¢Â€Â™s Eye for a beerÃ¢Â€Â™Ã¢Â€Â”there was this sense we
were all in it togetherÃ¢Â€Â”and youÃ¢Â€Â™d get into your car and
drive around the corner and have no trouble parking
right in front,Ã¢Â€Â the now-84-year-old Tony Norris says.
Ã¢Â€ÂœIt was that empty down here.Ã¢Â€Â
In the late Ã¢Â€Â™60s, John Waters, Glenn Milstead, aka Divine, and
friends began making pilgrimages to Fells Point, finding new partners
in subversion. MICA graduate Vincent Peraino, who was among
the influx of artists, became WatersÃ¢Â€Â™ set designer. Susan Lowe, a
painter who later dated Orye (some of her paintings still hang in the
CatÃ¢Â€Â™s Eye), appeared in nearly every Waters film. Other Fells Point
Dreamlanders included Mink Stole, George Figgs, Paul Swift, Peter
Koper, and Bob Adams. Ã¢Â€ÂœThe Hollywood Bakery, that was VincentÃ¢Â€Â™s
commune, and it was right next door to PeteÃ¢Â€Â™s Hotel, where Edith
Massey worked as a bartender and we hung out,Ã¢Â€Â Waters recalls with
a laugh. Ã¢Â€ÂœIt was the worst possible time down there and it was the
cheapest possible place. Drinks were 30 cents. Divine hated it. He
called it a Ã¢Â€Â˜hobo bar.Ã¢Â€Â™Ã¢Â€Â
Ã¢Â€ÂœFells Point was welcoming to all kinds of people,
that was the thing that was so amazing,Ã¢Â€Â Waters continues,
noting he once did a fashion shoot at the Apex
adult movie theater on Broadway, which somehow coexisted
among the churches and families in Upper
Fells. Ã¢Â€ÂœPaul Swift would jump up and dance naked
on the bars. They werenÃ¢Â€Â™t gay bars. It was gay and
straight. It was trans. Trans even then, and everybody
really got along. It was just cultural outlaws that didnÃ¢Â€Â™t
fit in their own minority.Ã¢Â€Â
Fells Point
Fun Festival, late 1960s,
with a Ã¢Â€ÂœStop The RoadÃ¢Â€Â
banner hanging on the
side of a building.Ã¢Â€Â”COURTESY OF THE SOCIETY FOR THE PRESERVATION OF FEDERAL HILL AND FELLÃ¢Â€Â™S POINT
According to Eney, one of then-Vice President Spiro
AgnewÃ¢Â€Â™s female staffers, who secretly supported the
Fells preservationists, passed their completed National Register forms to Agnew to speed approval. Not realizing the obstacle
that placement on National Register would present to the highway he
and local contractors favored, Agnew dutifully forwarded them on and
Ã¢Â€Âœin three days we were on the National Register,Ã¢Â€Â Eney recalled in 2004.
Ã¢Â€ÂœThe contractors were furious with
Agnew because he was so dumb. He had no idea what he had done.Ã¢Â€Â
The annual Fells Point Fun Festival, in fact, was first organized as
an anti-highway fundraising effort. At the 1969 annual street party,
Barbara Mikulski, a then-33-year-old social worker, shouted her opposition
as future Mayor William Donald Schaefer tried to make his case
for the highway. Ã¢Â€ÂœThe British couldnÃ¢Â€Â™t take Fells Point, the termites
couldnÃ¢Â€Â™t take Fells Point,Ã¢Â€Â announced Mikulski, part of group calling
themselves Radio Free Fells Point. Ã¢Â€ÂœAnd we donÃ¢Â€Â™t think the State Roads
Commission can take Fells Point either.Ã¢Â€Â
The granddaughter of Polish bakers, Mikulski is a link between
Fells PointÃ¢Â€Â™s long immigration history and the fight to the stop the
highway. Ã¢Â€ÂœMy great-grandmother landed in Fells Point somewhere at Ã¢Â€Â˜the foot of Broadway,Ã¢Â€Â™ which is what we called that
area then, not Fells Point,Ã¢Â€Â Mikulski says. Ã¢Â€ÂœWhen
she came to this country and lived on Chester
Street near Holy Rosary, she could read, but she
was from Poland. One of the things she did to learn
English was to buy a newspaper and go down to
the Broadway Market and practice the language
and the exchange of money, and so on. People were
helpful and she could trust that she wasnÃ¢Â€Â™t going
to be taken advantage of. The churches were like
settlement houses because they were bilingual.Ã¢Â€Â
Ã¢Â€ÂœIn terms of the battle of Ã¢Â€Â˜the Road,Ã¢Â€Â™ there was the
parochial crowd, the preservationists, , the business
ownersÃ¢Â€Â”we were all in it. Were the town hall meetings
contentious?Ã¢Â€Â Mikulski adds. Ã¢Â€ÂœItÃ¢Â€Â™s Bawlmer, hon.Ã¢Â€Â
The fundamental problem behind the conception of
Ã¢Â€Âœthe RoadÃ¢Â€ÂÃ¢Â€Â”including the stretch known as Ã¢Â€ÂœThe Highway
to NowhereÃ¢Â€Â that got built through majority-Black
West BaltimoreÃ¢Â€Â”is officials did not appreciate the value
of working-class neighborhoods, Mikulski says. Ã¢Â€ÂœThat
was certainly the attitude of Robert Moses,Ã¢Â€Â the New
York highway builder who first designed BaltimoreÃ¢Â€Â™s
planned east-west highway. Ã¢Â€ÂœHe did not see the value,
he didnÃ¢Â€Â™t see the jobs that were there, and he didnÃ¢Â€Â™t see
what I call the social capital. It was the relationships
that were, and are, important in those communities.Ã¢Â€Â
Cocina Luchadoras,
SophiaÃ¢Â€Â™s Place, and
CatÃ¢Â€Â™s Eye Pub.Ã¢Â€Â”PHOTOGRAPHY BY J.M. GIORDANO
Ã¢Â€ÂœItÃ¢Â€Â™s just not the same,Ã¢Â€Â Manuel Alvarez, a chief engineer for the
departed Baker-Whiteley tugboat company, told the same reporter,
adding he had little desire to visit Fells Point anymore. Ã¢Â€ÂœItÃ¢Â€Â™s just too...trendy. ItÃ¢Â€Â™s not just the way it used to be.Ã¢Â€Â
In an oral history a generation later, Ed Kane, who founded the
Baltimore water taxi operation in the Ã¢Â€Â™70s, said he thought Fells
Point Ã¢Â€Âœstill doesnÃ¢Â€Â™t know what it wants to be when it grows up.Ã¢Â€Â ItÃ¢Â€Â™s
been in Ã¢Â€Âœstate of transition,Ã¢Â€Â he said, for Ã¢Â€Âœmore than 200 years.Ã¢Â€Â
A ghost sign reading
Ã¢Â€ÂœVote Against ProhibitionÃ¢Â€Â
remains visible
today.-PHOTOGRAPHY BY J.M. GIORDANO
Society
for the Preservation of Federal Hill
and FellÃ¢Â€Â™s Point president David
Gleason sits in front of the
1765-built Robert Long House.-PHOTOGRAPHY BY J.M. GIORDANO
Ã¢Â€ÂœI get the new business owners and the changes,Ã¢Â€Â
Norris continues. Ã¢Â€ÂœI donÃ¢Â€Â™t hate it, like a lot of the oldtimers.
TheyÃ¢Â€Â™re coming from a good place. In their
minds, theyÃ¢Â€Â™re doing the best thing that they can do
for the neighborhood. I believe that. Now, is it the best
thing for the neighborhood? I donÃ¢Â€Â™t know. The thing
about Fells Point is that had so much character, and
characters, such charm. But people got older and sold
their places and the new people, who are buying them,
this is how they see their future.Ã¢Â€Â
Norris acknowledges the water and rowhouses will
be always be here. As will reappointed warehouses and
ThamesÃ¢Â€Â™ Belgian block streets. But what else?
Ã¢Â€ÂœWhat I guess I mean, is that a neighborhood or is
that just brick and stone?Ã¢Â€Â

EXAMINING HOPKINS HOSPITAL'S RELATIONSHIP WITH BALTIMORE
JOY
The Cover-Letter 2020
2020 Commencement Magazine
"Uprooted and displaced": How the East Baltimore Development Initiative gentrified Middle East
By RUDY MALCOM
| May 3, 2021
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that
supports HTML5 video
EBDI announced its master plan in 2001, revealing that 2000 rowhouses would be destroyed. Although most were vacant, hundreds of people were forcibly removed from their homes through the law of eminent domain, which allows the government to take private property for the benefit of the public after paying just compensation.
In her 2013 book Race, Class, Power, and Organizing in East Baltimore: Rebuilding Abandoned Communities in America, activist Dr. Marisela Gomez notes that â€œresidents were being forced to relocate with no plan for how they could return to benefit from this good.â€
EBDI originally lacked community representation in its planning process. As a result, the Save Middle East Action Committee (SMEAC) was formed. For years, SMEAC fought for fair compensation and relocation terms. The group disbanded in November 2009 and was later replaced by BRACE.
Although displaced residents were promised a path back, the area was a dead zone for a decade and a half due to slow progress. Investment and construction were further delayed by the Great Recession.
Gresham told The News-Letter that he didnâ€™t learn that his home was being acquired until a SMEAC organizer came to his house and told him.
â€œI didnâ€™t read it in the paper, I didnâ€™t get a letter, I didnâ€™t get any phone calls â€” all I knew was that they were acquiring my property,â€ he said. â€œYou would not have known it at all. They had no formal way of letting you know that your property was being acquired and you were going to have to move.â€
A 2018 article in the Baltimore Sun describes Gresham, who later became president of SMEAC, as â€œamong those who avoided displacement.â€ He emphasized to The News-Letter that he and a few dozen others were only able to do so because of years of advocacy.
â€œI didnâ€™t get displaced because it was designated for me to stay. No, it was more like they dragged out the process, and we had to do a rally and articles and so many things,â€ he said. â€œIt was a constant battle to get them to hear what we were saying and what they promised.â€
â€œI donâ€™t want to call it â€˜another Jim Crowâ€™â€
Gresham said that SMEAC had to fight â€œalmost day and nightâ€ for safe demolition. Middle East Baltimore Stories chronicles how demolition procedures led to property damage and rat infestations, as well as psychological strain that manifested as increased crime and physical ailments like asthma and lead poisoning.
Lead poisoning, which has long afflicted poor and Black youth in Baltimore, is known to decrease cognitive function, increase aggression and ultimately worsen the cycle of poverty fueled by racist policies like redlining.
A 2016 report by the Annie E. Casey Foundation attributes residentsâ€™ concerns about lead poisoning to a controversial study by the Bloomberg School of Public Health and the Kennedy Krieger Institute. In 2000, researchers spread fertilizer made from human and industrial waste on the lawns of several homes in East Baltimore. While Hopkins claimed that the fertilizer successfully mitigated lead and that the community had been informed, many activists and lawmakers questioned whether the experiment had exploited poor, Black families.
EBDI used wetting to reduce the spread of lead-contaminated dust during demolition. It also informed and educated residents extensively about planned construction, according to the report.
â€œThe demolition protocols developed for the East Baltimore Revitalization Initiative set a new national standard in the battle against lead poisoning and, more broadly, in the field of responsible redevelopment,â€ the report reads.
The authors of the report note that SMEAC had called for demolition to be paused until safety guarantees were implemented.
â€œEventually, EBDI and its partners agreed to work toward guaranteeing that demolition would not harm residents and took several key steps to achieve that goal,â€ the report reads.
Vernice Miller-Travis, a national leader in environmental justice who helped coin the term â€œenvironmental racism,â€ served as a member of an independent panel overseeing the demolition. In the report, she is quoted as commending EBDIâ€™s safety measures.
â€œI have not seen this level of caution and sensitivity in a community of color or low-income community in the U.S.,â€ she said. â€œIt sets a new bar about how community development should be done.â€
In the 1930s, the Home Ownerâ€™s Loan Corporation deemed non-white neighborhoods risky for mortgage support by outlining them in red on residential security maps. To this day, redlined neighborhoods in Baltimore are structurally disadvantaged. Ordinance 610, a 1911 housing segregation law in Baltimore, was a precursor to redlining nationwide. It was in part the legacy of a report initiated by the Universityâ€™s former president Daniel Coit Gilman.
About a century later, Daniels assumed Gilmanâ€™s position in 2009. In 2018, Daniels told The Guardian, â€œYou can make the moral case of why, given the bounty of resources that we have, itâ€™s incumbent on us to share with the city. But the other thing is to make clear that this is an enlightened form of self-interest. It is inconceivable that Hopkins would remain a pre-eminent institution in a city that continues to suffer decline.â€
As Baltimoreâ€™s largest private anchor institution and Marylandâ€™s largest private employer, Hopkins â€œseeks to create economic opportunities that are inclusive of diverse people and create wealth for individuals and communities.â€ This mission statement adorns the Universityâ€™s web page on HopkinsLocal, an initiative launched in 2015.
Due to the Universityâ€™s â€˜enlightened form of self-interest,â€™ Middle Eastâ€™s own neighborhood anchor institutions suffered. For instance, Middle East Baltimore Stories mentions that the Sweet Prospect Baptist Church had been debt-free for decades before it was demolished. Although EBDI helped the church move to a nearby neighborhood, the new building required hundreds of thousands of dollars of renovation.
â€œThe church received a building,â€ the book reads, â€œbut not a means to preserve the congregation.â€
Similarly, Gresham highlighted that people who had been living in the same place for four generations were uprooted by EBDI. During the Great Migration, thousands of Black people came to Baltimore to escape racism in the South and find employment.
â€œFamilies came here to have a better life only to later find out that itâ€™s almost like another â€” I donâ€™t want to call it â€˜another Jim Crowâ€™ â€” displacement of their lives. You put down your rootsâ€¦ and now someone says to you, â€˜This area is designated for the rich and famous, and the poor and poverty doesnâ€™t fit in,â€™â€ Gresham said. â€œCan you imagine what thatâ€™s like, when you were running away from something and running into something that almost has the same feeling?â€
How has Hopkins impacted neighboring communities of color?
EBDI states on its website that it is helping displaced residents return to what is now Eager Park by â€œdefraying closing and moving costs, narrowing financing gapsâ€ and ensuring that one third of houses are affordable.
According to the website, displaced renters received vouchers â€œto rent affordably throughout the region,â€ and homeowners received five times the value of their homes on average, allowing them to â€œmove mostly stable neighborhoods mortgage free.â€
However, many residents, Gresham said, already lacked financial stability before EBDI, making them unlikely to return.
In 2018, the Baltimore Sun reported that â€œjust one in 10 displaced residents has returned or plans to, and fewer than a quarter have expressed interest.â€ President and CEO of EBDI Cheryl Washington told the Baltimore Sun that EBDI hired a consultant to track down displaced residents with whom it had lost touch.
Gresham questioned the EBDIâ€™s ability to do so. Many residents moved out quickly, he said, and have been scattered across the city for almost two decades.
Additionally, though an EBDI survey found that â€œ85 percent of displaced residents said they were better off after being relocated,â€ Gresham explained why this statistic is misleading.
â€œYou have to imagine the pain and uncomfortableness. First, you move me out like Iâ€™m a cattle and then you tell me, â€˜Yeah, you can get back, but read the survey,â€™â€ he said. â€œMany people didnâ€™t even respond to the survey because they were devastated.â€
Between January 2006 and September 2018, EBDI has yielded 288 hires from Baltimore, only 23 of whom were EBDI-impacted residents.
Since EBDI began, 490 local workers have retained employment by working on EBDI projects. Almost 40% of them are from Baltimore (161 of them from minority groups), and a quarter of them are from East Baltimore (107 from minority groups).
â€œThey came in and disrupted our lives. We thought that money would help to build businesses not only for the community, but by the community and with the community. That didnâ€™t happen,â€ Gresham said. â€œThe reinvestment money could have been a blessing for so many reasons.â€
Gresham added that activists had to push for the public school that was built, Elmer A. Henderson: A Johns Hopkins Partnership School, to allocate more spots to children of color in nearby areas.

Black Baltimoreans fight to save homes from redevelopment
1 of 9|Vacant homes, including one, bottom left, once rented by Angela Banks are visible with boarded doors and windows, Wednesday, Feb. 15, 2023, in Baltimore. In 2018, Banks was told by her landlord that Baltimore officials were buying her familyâ€™s home of four decades, planning to demolish the three-story brick rowhouse to make room for an urban renewal project aimed at transforming their historically Black neighborhood. Banks and her children became homeless almost overnight. Banks filed a complaint Monday asking federal officials to investigate whether Baltimoreâ€™s redevelopment policies are perpetuating racial segregation and violating fair housing laws by disproportionately displacing Black and low-income residents. (AP Photo/Julio Cortez)

ByLea Skene
Share
Share
Copy
Link copied
Email

Print
BALTIMORE (AP) â€” In 2018, Angela Banks received bad news from her landlord: Baltimore officials were buying her familyâ€™s home of four decades, planning to demolish the three-story brick row house to make room for a beleaguered urban renewal project aimed at transforming a historically Black neighborhood. Banks and her children became homeless almost overnight. With nowhere else to go, they spent months sleeping in her aging Ford Explorer. Roughly five years later, the house remains standing, and plans to redevelop west Baltimoreâ€™s Poppleton neighborhood have largely stalled, even after the city displaced Banks and many of her neighbors.Banks filed a complaint Monday asking federal officials to investigate whether Baltimoreâ€™s redevelopment policies are perpetuating racial segregation and violating fair housing laws by disproportionately displacing Black and low-income residents. Her experience presents the latest example of Black Baltimoreans losing their homes to redevelopment after watching their neighborhoods suffer from growing disinvestment â€” while whiter, more affluent communities flourish, Banks and her attorneys argue.
Other news
NYC mayor vetoes bill expanding reporting of police stops, faces override by City Council
NOT REAL NEWS: A look at what didnâ€™t happen this week
Melania Trump remembers her mother as â€˜a ray of light in the darkest daysâ€™
Once relatively common in American cities, using the practice for revitalization and infrastructure projects has largely fallen out of favor. Some cities are currently working to provide reparations to Black residents, acknowledging the harm caused by urban renewal efforts and other discriminatory practices. Banks reminisced about her children swimming in Poppletonâ€™s public pool while she socialized with neighbors on their stoops. Since then, over 100 occupied homes have been seized, according to the complaint. The pool and nearby recreation center closed years ago, Banks said. Poppleton is about 93% Black, according to 2020 census data.â€œBaltimore has long been a tale of two cities,â€ said Marceline White, executive director of Economic Action Maryland, which joined Banks in filing the complaint and organized a news conference Monday in Poppleton. In 1910, Baltimore leaders enacted the countryâ€™s first residential segregation ordinance that restricted African American homeowners to certain blocks. In addition to redlining, Poppleton residents experienced â€œslum clearanceâ€ starting in the 1930s with construction of Poe Homes, a public housing complex named after a nearby onetime residence of the famous poet Edgar Allan Poe. The number of displaced Black families was larger than the number of housing units created, according to the complaint.
Then came Baltimoreâ€™s so-called â€œHighway To Nowhere,â€ which was designed to connect the downtown business district to interstates surrounding the city. Officials used eminent domain to demolish nearly 1,000 homes in the 1960s and â€™70s, cutting a swath through majority-Black west Baltimore and severing ties between Poppleton and other nearby communities.Construction of the thoroughfare was never finished â€” partly because residents in more affluent neighborhoods successfully campaigned against it â€” and the endeavor became largely pointless. â€œWhatâ€™s happening now in Poppleton is a reflection of what has happened before, part of an unbroken chain of policies and practices,â€ said Lawrence Brown, a research scientist at Morgan State University. â€œThere is a pattern.â€Plans for Poppletonâ€™s urban renewal surfaced in the 1970s. By that time, Brown said, the neighborhood had already been experiencing mistreatment and disinvestment for decades. In 2006, city officials signed an agreement with a New York-based company, La Cite Development. Construction has been completed on two mixed-use buildings with 262 rental units, but many other aspects of the $800 million project havenâ€™t materialized. Initial plans identified over 500 properties the company would redevelop near a University of Maryland biomedical research park, just outside the downtown business district.
